snippet: After at least 155 people were killed in a car bombing in Baghdad, Iraq’s leader tried to assuage the public’s anger and grief by speeding the executions of militants....
abstract: Grief over deaths of more than 150 people killed in car bombing in Iraq gives way to anger as residents begin protests demanding that officials, including Prime Min Haider al-Abadi, resign.

byline.original: By FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
byline.contributor: Falih Hassan reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Beirut, Lebanon. Omar Al-Jawoshy contributed reporting from Baghdad.

lead_paragraph: After at least 155 people were killed in a car bombing in Baghdad, Iraq’s leader tried to assuage the public’s anger and grief by speeding the executions of militants.

headline.main: ISIS Bombing in Baghdad Casts Doubt on Iraqi Leader’s Ability to Unite
headline.print_headline: Grief Over Bombing Turns to Anger at Iraq’s Political Leaders

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
